newsitem.title: GERMANY: German state deports 10 Bosnian refugees home.
newsitem.headline: German state deports 10 Bosnian refugees home.

text.p: Germany's largest state North Rhine-Wesphalia deported 25 Bosnians on Tuesday, a spokesman for the regional government in Duesseldorf said.

Included in the group were 10 single Bosnians or married people without children. Their involuntary departure marked the first time that the state had deported a group of Bosnian refugees not previously convicted of any crimes in Germany.
A group of 16 convicted criminals were sent home from the state in April and another eight convicts were deported on Tuesday, the spokesman said.
Seven other Bosnians who had arrived in Germany after the 1995 Dayton peace agreement were also sent back to Bosnia on Tuesday on a plane bound for Sarajevo.
The refugees were deported as part of an agreement between Bonn and Germany's 16 states that if the refugees failed to return to Bosnian voluntarily, they eventually faced forced repatriation.
With memories of World War Two still poignant, Germans welcomed the refugees with open arms taking in some 320,000 -- more than the rest of the European Union.
But facing record unemployment and economic decline at home, Germans started to complain the Bosnians were becoming a burden on increasingly tight state finances.
Refugee agencies have criticised Germany's policy of forced repatriation, arguing that most returnees ended up in refugee camps in the chaotic aftermath of the 1992-95 war.

The state government spokesman said about 9,000 of 66,000 Bosnian refugees who took shelter in North Rhine-Westphalia had already volunteered to return to Bosnia. About 20,000 Bosnians across Germany have returned home of their own accord.

The southern state of Bavaria and the northern state of Berlin, both of which are led by conservative parties, have already deported scores of Bosnians. North Rhine-Westphalia is governed by the left-leaning Social Democrats.
